Arbitrage why was this the case and how

think the reason why that is the case
and it is even more the case today than

statistical arbitr is inherently a

your typical average holding period for
this type of strategy can range anywhere

the more turnover you have the more

the shorter term you are the more trade
execution costs become an integral part
of the alpha you are delivering and the

average holding period so the shorter
your average holding period the more

then there's a second factor that is not
to be forgotten that's your gross
exposure so the more cross exposure you
need to run or your Alpha consumes the
more turnover you will face obviously
because you will trade more more
notional in terms of notional and so one
of the key metrics you look at when you
manage a statiscal arbitrage strategy is
your return on Gross exposure that

it summarize very well what you're doing
how much Alpha can you extract per unit

training strategy because the higher

Alpha that's the alpha that is left

approach to Trend thring or relative
risk adjusted approach to measuring
Trends and the initial motivation behind

obviously capital is moving from one

one investment opportunity to the next
and the question was okay how can we
model

if you have 100 instruments we'll look

cence or correlation structure of these

between these different instruments how
does this approach end up being

cross-sectional momentum so we get asked

could essentially think of this approach
as cross-sectional but in reality if we
think about what cross-sectional
momentum is about cross-section momentum
is something that's pretty standard in
the equity space so you measure for
instance the 12 month momentum indicator
for every stock in your investment
universe and you cross normalize that so
for a given point in time across all the
instruments that compose your investment
Universe one thing that is worth
mentioning is that when you do that
across a universe of 100 Futures like we
do like the typical CTA investment
Universe the cross-section momentum
measured in that way is not so different
from time series momentum because you
can think of it that the average
correlation between all the Futures that
you trade in a CTA is relatively low so
when you cross normalize think of it as
just the average between the performance
of all these markets it's not going to
make a very big difference compared to
the time series momentum that enters
into that measure so you have a
relationship that cross-section momentum
will
deviate more relative to time series
momentum the more correlated the
constituents are of your investment
universe so if you look at it on an
asset class by asset class basis in a
CTA Universe you tend to have the
highest correlation the highest cross
coration in the equity space and so when
you do cross-section momentum per asset
class if you compare time series
momentum and crosssection momentum you
you will have to see the largest
difference in terms of the information
you capture on equities and then on
commodities which have the lowest cross
correlation between the constituents you
will see less of a difference so it's
not completely trivial to exploit cross
asset information from a trend
perspective because if you look at it at
the entire universe it's not really
different so just in a purely standard
way it doesn't really make a difference
and on a asset class by asset class

information elements but you are missing

because you do it asset class by asset

mum where you compare each instrument in
